importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2025 onwards has seen a surge in extreme weather events globally, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, prompting urgent calls for improved early-warning systems.

Over the past 50 years, weather, water, and climate-related hazards have caused over 2 million deaths, with 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries, underscoring the long-term human and economic toll of climate-related disasters.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions, especially in developing nations, at risk.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, highlighting the life-saving potential of such systems.
90% of weather-related deaths over 50 years have occurred in developing countries, indicating disproportionate vulnerability.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52 in 2015), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is especially severe in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action and aims to empower communities rather than just warn them.
Real-world examples like the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland demonstrate how early monitoring and alerts can save lives through timely evacuations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has issued a global call to action to close critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capacity. With climate change intensifying weather disasters, the WMO reports that over 2 million people have died from weather-related hazards in the past 50 years, with 90% of deaths occurring in developing nations. Despite progress—such as an increase from 52 to 108 countries using early warning systems—the assessment reveals that half of 62 assessed countries still have only basic or insufficient systems, especially in fragile or conflict-affected regions. The article highlights real-world examples, including the May 2025 evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, after a predicted glacier collapse, and widespread disasters such as floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the U.S., underscoring the urgent need for global investment in early-warning infrastructure to save lives and protect infrastructure.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
